benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/catalog - Delete all versions for a per tenant catalog

covered: DELETE - Valid Deletion: Successful deletion returns 204 and removes all catalog versions (TC01, TC02, TC05, TC08, TC10, TC12, TC15).
DELETE - Non-Existent Resource: Proper handling for non-existent tenant (404) and tenant with no versions (still 204) (TC05, TC06).
DELETE - Concurrency: Concurrent requests handled; only one effective delete, others receive 204/404 as appropriate (TC13).
Error Handling: Missing required header (400/401), invalid/expired token (401), malformed headers (400), system failure (500) (TC03, TC04, TC07, TC09).
Security/Validation Hardening: Injection/malicious header values rejected (400/422) (TC11).
Optional Headers Behavior: Reason/Comment optional and accepted when present (TC02).
Side-effects Verification: Post-delete GET shows empty/404; ensures data actually removed and no orphaned references (TC01, TC12).
Non-standard input: Request body on DELETE is ignored while still succeeding (TC15).
Performance: Large number of versions still deleted within acceptable time (TC10).
gaps: DELETE - Soft Deletes: No explicit verification of soft-delete vs hard-delete behavior (e.g., flags, retrievability via admin/audit endpoints).
Authorization/Permissions granularity: No scenario for authenticated but unauthorized user (403 Forbidden) distinct from invalid token (401).
Idempotency: No explicit sequential test that a second DELETE after successful deletion returns a consistent/defined status (e.g., 204 or 404) and remains side-effect-free.
Tenant Isolation: No test ensuring deletion for one tenant does not impact catalogs of other tenants.
Audit Trail Persistence: No verification that X-Killbill-CreatedBy/Reason/Comment are recorded in audit logs/history for the delete operation.
Rate/Abuse Controls: No scenario covering burst DELETE attempts beyond concurrency (e.g., throttling/429) if applicable to the API policy.
recommendations: Add a soft-delete verification scenario (or explicitly assert hard-delete) by attempting to retrieve deleted versions via any admin/list endpoints or checking deletion flags and ensuring permanent removal is intended.
Add a 403 Forbidden scenario where the user is authenticated but lacks permission to delete catalogs for the tenant.
Add an idempotency scenario: perform DELETE twice sequentially and assert the defined behavior (e.g., first 204, second 404 or 204) with no side effects.
Add a tenant isolation scenario: seed two tenants; delete for tenant A; verify tenant B catalog versions remain intact.
Add an audit trail scenario: after DELETE with CreatedBy/Reason/Comment, query audit logs/history to confirm these values are persisted.
If applicable, add throttling/abuse scenario for rapid repeated DELETEs to validate 429 or documented behavior.
